reasoning: The critique targets the post’s illustrative claim that (in an extreme limit) cognitive labor could fully substitute for compute by “simulating NNs in their heads,” used to motivate that a hard complementarity (ρ<0) can’t hold in the absolute limit. Refuting this weakens one intuition pump for high substitutability, but it is not a necessary pillar of the overall anti-bottleneck case (which also rests on long-run reconfiguration, experiment-efficiency gains, extrapolation limits of CES, non-frontier experiments, etc.), so centrality is modest. On the specific attacked point, the critique is strong: it correctly notes that “mental simulation” still requires physical operations on some substrate, so it does not evade FLOP/energy/memory constraints and doesn’t by itself show compute can be substituted away. The critique is mostly correct and clearly stated, with little extraneous material, and it stays focused on a single issue. Overall it’s a good local objection but only a moderate problem for the broader position.
title: Mental simulation cannot substitute compute, so negative ρ remains plausible under fixed hardware
